head.title: The Accidental Journalist: A Teenager Finds a Vocation

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New York
Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Technology, Telecommunications and Internet

hedline.hl1: The Accidental Journalist: A Teenager Finds a Vocation

abstract.p: Tameeka Mitchem is editor in chief Harlem Live, a nonprofit Web site produced by teenagers that publishes news and features concerning Harlem, mostly on its community-based organizations; photo (S)

block.p: TAMEEKA MITCHEM remembers her first foray into journalism as something of a disaster. In April 1999, she volunteered to work for Harlem Live, a nonprofit Web site (www.harlemlive.org) produced by New York teenagers. When another reporter could not make a scheduled interview at a local community organization, Tameeka went instead.
''I was so nervous, and that's weird because I'm not a nervous person,'' she said. ''I was reading the information in the cab on the way over. I think I asked one question three times.''

TAMEEKA MITCHEM remembers her first foray into journalism as something of a disaster. In April 1999, she volunteered to work for Harlem Live, a nonprofit Web site (www.harlemlive.org) produced by New York teenagers. When another reporter could not make a scheduled interview at a local community organization, Tameeka went instead.
''I was so nervous, and that's weird because I'm not a nervous person,'' she said. ''I was reading the information in the cab on the way over. I think I asked one question three times.''

Six months later, Tameeka was Harlem Live's editor in chief, helping to manage the Web site's staff of more than 30. The site, created in the mid-90's, publishes news and features concerning Harlem, mostly on community-based organizations that, she said, ''don't get all that much attention.''
Tameeka was not interested in being a reporter or an editor when she joined Harlem Live. ''I was looking for something to put on my college application,'' she said.
It worked. In a few months, she will leave the site to attend college in Virginia. Her major: journalism.
